poem:
Route 21 rumbles through midnight arteries,  
its diesel breath fogging the neon glass,  
each headlight carving a path across worn asphalt.  

It barrels past a possum frozen in the sheen of streetlamp—  
no mercy in its gears, no mercy in its schedule.  
Steel resolve wrapped in a shell of scratched paint.  

The driver leans forward with a grin that cracks like sidewalk,  
“I once outran a midnight storm  
on two flat tires,” he says—  
words strung on the wind, half truth, half dare.  

Windows vibrate to the city’s pulse:  
distant sirens, a thief’s soft footsteps,  
the hush of late-night vendors packing crates of fish.  
Every stop a promise, every acceleration a challenge.  

At point forty-three the route splits—  
one finger pointing to the glowing tower,  
the other to shadowed alleys humming with whispers.  
Riders cling to handrails as stories unfold,  
pulled along by a machine  
both strict in its purpose and eager for legend.  

By dawn, the city exhales in pink and gray,  
Route 21 slowing only for the call of its own myth—  
never for a possum, always for the next tale.
